title: JD Vance's pastoral vacation in the English countryside included an unlicensed fishing trip with the British foreign secretary
description: David Lammy was given a written warning for fishing without a license after he self-reported to the Environment Agency. He didn't catch anything.
content:
British Foreign Secretary David Lammy went fishing with U.S. Vice President JD Vance earlier this month and the closest thing he came to catching was a whopping fine.

Lammy was given a written warning for fishing without a license, an Environment Agency spokesperson said Friday.

As far as breaking the law goes, it was pretty small fry but could have netted him a fine of up to 2,500 pounds ($3,380) for the offense.

Lammy, whose spokesperson described it all as an “administrative oversight,” purchased a license after-the-fact and reported himself to the agency.

Lammy hosted Vance and his family, who were vacationing in England, at his country estate south of London on Aug. 8. The two men smiled and laughed as Vance provided what Lammy called Kentucky-style fishing tips.

“The one strain on the special relationship is that all of my kids caught fish, but the foreign secretary did not,” Vance later said.

The Environment Agency would not comment on whether Vance had a license, citing data protection rules. The vice president’s spokesperson did not immediately reply to an email from The Associated Press seeking comment.

The agency said it confirmed that Lammy was given a warning because he had publicized it. In England and Wales, anyone over 13 needs a license for freshwater fishing, the agency said.

In most cases, inexperienced anglers caught without a permit are given warnings — so in that sense, Lammy apparently had some beginner’s luck.
summary: British Foreign Secretary David Lammy was given a written warning for fishing without a license during a fishing trip with U.S. Vice President JD Vance. Lammy purchased a license after-the-fact and reported himself to the Environment Agency. The Environment Agency confirmed that Lammy had publicized the incident and could face a fine of up to 2,500 pounds ($3,380).
shortSummary: British Foreign Secretary David Lammy took an unlicensed fishing trip with US Vice President JD Vance, earning a warning from the Environment Agency.
argos_summary: British Foreign Secretary David Lammy went fishing with U.S. Vice President J.D. Vance at his country estate and was issued a written warning for fishing without a license, a minor offence that could have carried a fine of up to £2,500. Lammy quickly purchased a license and reported himself to the Environment Agency, describing the incident as an administrative oversight. Vance and his family were vacationing in England, and while the agency declined to comment on whether Vance had a license, the event highlighted the importance of proper licensing for freshwater fishing in England and Wales.
